source.document_id: The relationship between chest tube size and c

metadata.title: The Relationship Between Chest Tube Size and Clinical Outcome in Pleural Infection

sections.abstract: Background: The optimal choice of chest tube size for the treatment of pleural infection is unknown, with only small cohort studies reported describing the efficacy and adverse events of different tube sizes. Methods: A total of 405 patients with pleural infection were prospectively enrolled into a multi-center study investigating the utility of fibrinolytic therapy. The combined frequency of death and surgery, and secondary outcomes (hospital stay, change in chest radiograph, and lung function at 3 months) were compared in patients receiving chest tubes of differing size (chi-square, t test, and logistic regression analyses as appropriate). Pain was studied in detail in 128 patients. Results: There was no significant difference in the frequency with which patients either died or required thoracic surgery in patients receiving chest tubes of varying sizes (<10F: 21/58 [36%]; 10-14F: 75/208 [36%]; 15-20F: 28/70 [40%]; >20F: 30/69 [44%]; chi-square trend 1 df = 1.21, P = .27), nor any difference in any secondary outcome. Pain scores were substantially higher in patients receiving (mainly blunt dissection-inserted) larger tubes (<10F median pain score 6 [range 4-7]; 10-14F 5 [4-6]; 15-20F 6 [5-7]; >20F 6 [6-8]; chi-square 3 df = 10.80, P = .013; chi-square trend 1 df = 6.3, P = .014). Conclusions: Smaller, guide-wire-inserted chest tubes cause substantially less pain than blunt-dissection-inserted larger tubes, without any impairment in clinical outcome in the treatment of pleural infection. These results suggest that smaller size tubes may be the initial treatment of choice for pleural infection, and randomized studies are now required. Trial registration: ISRCTN39138989.
sections.methods: This is a predefined observational analysis within the MIST1 randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of intrapleural streptokinase vs placebo in pleural infection. Four hundred fifty-four patients were recruited from 52 UK centers; detailed chest tube size data were available for 405 patients. Inclusion criteria were pleural fluid that was macroscopically purulent, positive on culture, positive on Gram stain, or pH < 7.2 in a patient with clinical evidence of infection. Chest tube size and insertion technique (guide-wire [Seldinger] vs blunt dissection) were chosen by treating clinicians. Saline flushes were used for tubes <14F; suction of -20 cm H2O was applied to all tubes. Primary endpoint was death or need for thoracic surgery up to 12 months. Secondary endpoints included death alone, surgery alone, length of hospital stay, chest radiograph improvement, and FEV1/FVC at 3 months. Pain was assessed via questionnaire in 128 patients (insertion, in-situ, removal). Statistical methods included chi-square tests (including trend), Mann-Whitney U, Kruskal-Wallis, Kaplan-Meier/log-rank, and logistic regression adjusting for known prognostic factors (e.g., age, urea, albumin, diastolic BP, hospital-acquired infection, bacteriology class).
sections.results: Among 405 patients with known tube size, the composite of death or thoracic surgery at 12 months did not differ by tube size (<10F 21/58 [36%]; 10-14F 75/208 [36%]; 15-20F 28/70 [40%]; >20F 30/69 [44%]; chi-square trend 1 df = 1.21, P = .27). Time-to-event curves were similar (log-rank chi-square 3 df = 1.58, P = .66). After logistic regression adjusting for known prognostic covariates, tube size was not associated with the composite endpoint (P for tube size in model = .96). Secondary outcomes showed no significant differences across tube sizes: death at 1 year (10/58 vs 46/208 vs 18/70 vs 17/69; P = .67), surgery at 1 year (11/58 vs 35/208 vs 13/70 vs 13/69; P = .97), hospital stay (means [SD] 26 [29] vs 24 [32] vs 31 [39] vs 28 [23] days; ANOVA F = 1.04, P = .37), FEV1 at 3 months (2.46 [1.0] vs 2.16 [0.79] vs 2.30 [0.88] vs 2.15 [0.90] L; ANOVA F = 1.17, P = .32), and FVC at 3 months (3.30 [1.19] vs 2.98 [0.98] vs 3.18 [1.13] vs 2.84 [1.00] L; ANOVA F = 1.42, P = .24). In subgroup analysis of patients with purulent fluid, smaller tubes were favored (12/42 [29%] vs 55/164 [34%] vs 25/58 [43%] vs 29/65 [45%]; chi-square trend 1 df = 4.3, P = .04). Nonpurulent subgroup showed a borderline trend (9/16 [56%] vs 20/44 [46%] vs 3/12 [25%] vs 1/4 [25%]; chi-square trend 1 df = 3.0, P = .08). Pain scores were higher with larger tubes and with blunt-dissection technique; overall pain Kruskal-Wallis chi-square 3 df = 10.80, P = .013; trend chi-square 1 df = 7.29, P = .008.

population.text: Adults with pleural infection enrolled in the MIST1 trial across 52 UK centers.
inclusion_criteria: Pleural fluid pH < 7.2 with clinical evidence of infection
exclusion_criteria: Not reported in this secondary analysis

intervention.details: Insertion mainly by guide-wire (Seldinger) technique; tubes <14F were flushed with 30 mL saline three times daily; suction -20 cm H2O applied.

comparison.details: Primarily inserted by blunt dissection; suction -20 cm H2O applied.

outcomes.name: Death or need for thoracic surgery by 12 months

design.study_type: Secondary analysis of RCT (observational comparison by tube size within MIST1)
design.allocation: nonrandomized for tube size; randomized for streptokinase vs placebo (not analyzed here)
design.blinding: open-label with respect to tube size; double-blind for streptokinase vs placebo

analysis_populations.name: Tube size dataset
analysis_populations.description: All participants with recorded chest tube size

analysis_populations.name: Pain subset
analysis_populations.description: Participants who completed the pain questionnaire

analysis_populations.name: Purulent subgroup
analysis_populations.description: Participants with visibly purulent pleural fluid and known tube size

outcomes_normalized.name: Death or thoracic surgery by 12 months (by chest tube size)

analysis.model: Cochran-Armitage trend test across ordered tube size categories
analysis.missing_handling: Complete-case for participants with recorded tube size

outcomes_normalized.name: Death or thoracic surgery by 12 months (adjusted logistic regression for tube size effect)

analysis.model: Logistic regression (composite outcome) with tube size as predictor

provenance.quote: After adjustment, there remained no relationship between chest tube size and mortality or surgery (P value for contribution to the model by tube size = .96).

outcomes_normalized.name: Death at 12 months (by chest tube size)
Thoracic surgery at 12 months (by chest tube size)
Death or thoracic surgery by 12 months in purulent pleural fluid subgroup

analysis.model: Cochran-Armitage trend test across ordered tube size categories (purulent subgroup)

outcomes_normalized.name: Death or thoracic surgery by 12 months in nonpurulent pleural fluid subgroup

analysis.model: Cochran-Armitage trend test across ordered tube size categories (nonpurulent subgroup)

outcomes_normalized.name: Death or thoracic surgery by 12 months (by insertion technique)

analysis.model: Unadjusted odds ratio with chi-square test

outcomes_normalized.name: FEV1 at 3 months (by chest tube size)
FVC at 3 months (by chest tube size)
Hospital stay (days) by chest tube size

domains.name: Confounding
domains.support_for_judgment: Chest tube size and insertion technique were not randomized and were strongly correlated; although logistic regression adjusted for known prognostic variables, residual confounding cannot be excluded.

domains.name: Selection of participants
domains.support_for_judgment: Consecutive trial participants with recorded tube size; 405/454 (89%) had detailed tube data.

domains.name: Classification of interventions
domains.support_for_judgment: Tube sizes and insertion methods were prospectively recorded and verified during trial monitoring.

domains.name: Deviations from intended interventions
domains.support_for_judgment: Management protocols (suction, saline flushes for small tubes) were described; no evidence of systematic deviations affecting outcomes.

domains.name: Missing data
domains.support_for_judgment: 11% lacked exact tube size; analyses used complete cases.

domains.name: Measurement of outcomes
domains.support_for_judgment: Objective outcomes (death, surgery); lung function measured; radiographs read blinded.

domains.name: Selection of reported result
domains.support_for_judgment: Preplanned analyses reported, including subgroup analyses.

retrieval.summary_tldr: Across 405 patients with pleural infection, smaller chest tubes (≤14F) did not worsen death/surgery rates at 12 months but were associated with substantially less pain; no differences in hospital stay or lung function.
retrieval.clinical_relevance: Supports initial use of small-bore, guide-wire-inserted chest tubes for pleural infection without compromising clinical outcomes.
